titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the John T. Yates, Jr. Papers, 1960-2015 UA.90.F106
titlestmt.author: Cassidee Knott.

note.p: Series X added to the finding aid in June 2024.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-07-08 17:35:18 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: John T. Yates, Jr., an American chemist, physicist, and astronomer, was born in 1935 in Winchester, Virginia, and died in 2015 in Free Union, Virginia. Yates attended Juniata College, where he received a Bachelor's degree in Chemistry in 1956, and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he received his Ph.D. in Physical Chemistry in 1960. After graduation, Yates served as an Assistant Professor at Antioch College in Ohio from 1960 to 1963. Yates then proceeded to work at the National Bureau of Standards in Washington, D.C from 1965 to 1981. During his time at the NBS, he was a visiting professor at the University of East Anglia and California Institute of Technology.

In 1982, Yates settled at the University of Pittsburgh, where he served as the first R.K. Mellon Professor of Chemistry from 1982 to 2006. While at Pitt, Yates was the Founding Director of the Surface Science Center, his specialized field. In 1994, he was given appointment to the Physics and Astronomy departments. Yates was the lead researcher in creating a coating that detected biochemical dangers in the air for the Defense Advanced Research Project Agency in 2001. In 2004, Yates was a head researcher in studies on carbon nanotubes, dubbed the World's Smallest Test Tubes. In 2006, he aided in the creation of semi-conductor islands smaller than 10 nanometers called Quantum Dots, which was an integral step toward the creation of Quantum computers. After retiring from Pitt in 2007, Yates joined the University of Virginia as a Shannon Research Fellow and Professor. During this time, Yates found himself involved in astrochemistry. Yates was the winner of various awards both locally and internationally. He was also a member of numerous scientific organizations, notably the National Academy of Sciences.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The collection covers the research, publications, patent, teaching, and professional activities of John T. Yates, Jr., as well as his awards and honors. The collection provides an overview of Yates' carreer at the National Bureau of Standards, the University of Pittsburgh, and the University of Virginia. Each series spans the wide variety of interests that Yates had throughout his career.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Karen Yates in August 2016 and 2021.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Cassidee Knott in May 2018.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: John T. Yates, Jr. Papers, 1960-2015, UA.90.F106, University Archives, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

controlaccess.subject: Surface chemistry
University of Pittsburgh
Chemistry -- Study and teaching (Higher) -- Pennsylvania -- Pittsburgh

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The series includes research done by John T. Yates, Jr. during his time at the National Bureau of Standards, the University of Pittsburgh, and the University of Virginia. Files may include his notes, annotated articles, drawings, and proposals. Topics include carbon nanotubes, atomic sources, carbon monoxide, desorption spectrometer, and the overarching topic of surface chemistry. Also included are journals containing notes on lectures that Yates attended spanning from 2000 to 2014 on subjects such as Astronomy, Scanning Tunnel Microscope, and general Surface Science.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The series contains a sampling of the publication authored by John T. Yates, Jr. Included are magazine articles, reviews, book chapters, obituaries, and a publishing agreement

did.unittitle: Notes on Molecular Physical Chemistry for Engineers Book
Nuclear Research Facility Interface Research and Vacuum Physics Scientific Publications
Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America Frontiers in Surface Chemistry

The Search for the Active Site on Catalysis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains material pertaining to Yates' 2005 patent titled "Decontamination of Chemical Warfare Agents Using Reactive Sorbent." Included are graphs, correspondence, research, information about the patent process, and the patent.

did.unittitle: Patent on Decontamination of Chemical Warfare Agents Using a Reactiver Sorbent

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The series includes topics concerning Yates' time at the University of Pittsburgh. These files comprise his work on the Surface Science Center, interactions with the Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, floor plans for Alumni Hall, and correspondence between Yates and campus administrators, including Chancellor Wesley Posvar.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The series covers teaching material used by Yates in classes such as, Chemistry 1420, Chemistry 1480, Chemistry 3420, and Chemistry 3610. These materials include student readings, lecture slides, problem sets, schedules, notes, and syllabi. This series includes information on courses Yates taught at the University of Pittsburgh, University of Virginia, and various visiting appointments

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes newspaper clippings, magazine articles, and published works on the career of John T. Yates, Jr. The articles are arranged according to his time at the National Bureau of Standards, the University of Pittsburgh, and the University of Virginia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The series is a collection of letters and emails sent to and by John T. Yates, Jr. Included are correspondence with students, colleagues, and politicians, among others.

did.unittitle: National Bureau of Standards, Employee Evaluation
What's New with Bob Park Emails

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The series includes information about events and professional travel during John T. Yates, Jr.'s career. Calendars, lectures and conference information, as well as notes regarding trips abroad, are present in this series.

did.unittitle: Review Meeting for Research of Catalysis Research Center
National Research Council Workshop on Assessing the Value of Research in Chemical Sciences
International Symposium on Surface Science and Nanotechnology

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The series includes correspondence, nominations, and programs regarding the various awards given to John T. Yates, Jr. over the course of his career. These awards span from local to international recognitions, including his appointment to the National Academy of Science, his visiting professorship to the California Institute of Technology, and the Langmuir award. The collection also includes nominations for awards Yates did not receive.

did.unittitle: American Association for the Advancement of Science Award
American Chemical Society, Chemical and Physics Award
California Institute of Technology Visiting Professor
Humboldt Research Award for Senior U.S. Scientists

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains presentations, course materials, and research pertaining to Yates' interests in chemistry and surface science. Also included are corresponence with colleagues and students, as well as information about awards and events held in his honor. Of note are photographs of events attended by Yates, trips abroad, and students he worked with at the University of Pittsburgh.
